feed.title: TV preview: Raising Hope

link.title: Raising Hope

category.term: 291~Martha Plimpton~Parks and Recreation (TV Show)~Raising Hope~Greg Garcia
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
Raising Hope raises hopes for cute-yet-sophisticated TV comedy again tonight, with an episode in which a raccoon takes up residence under the Chances' family porch, and Virginia (Martha Plimpton) and Sabrina (Shannon Woodward) try to lure the critter out without waking up the neighbourhood. Faster than you can say, "And how's that working out?" it all goes sideways.

Meanwhile, in another wry comment on burning social issues of the day, baby Hope is starting to misbehave - so Burt (Garret Dillahunt) suggests it might be time for Jimmy to spank her, as that particular parenting technique worked so well for Jimmy when he was growing up.

Raising Hope, now in its second season, seems assured of renewal for a third, even as similarly clever, heartfelt comedies like Community and Parks and Recreation teeter on the brink. The reason Raising Hope may survive, where Parks and Recreation and Community fail, has as much to do with luck, scheduling and being on the right network at the right time, as it does the quality of the comedy.

Raising Hope's creator, Greg Garcia, had a minor success with the Jaime Pressly and Jason Lee comedy, My Name Is Earl, which (ironically) aired on the very same network and at the very same time as Community and Parks and Recreation.

Now, with Raising Hope, Garcia looks as if he has a sitcom that will allow fans to watch baby Hope as she grows up, becomes a toddler, and perhaps makes it into grade school.

At an atypically casual, laid-back session with reporters earlier this year, Plimpton and Garcia talked about life, Hope and long-lasting TV series.

The Chance family is nuts, but when Hope grows up, Plimpton vowed that, as an actor playing a part, her onscreen granddaughter won't turn out to be as crazy as her character, or her character's extended family.

"Never," Plimpton said, keeping a straight face. "I will never allow that."

Plimpton believes Raising Hope comes by its mix of gentle, warm-hearted humour and its portrait of economic disparity - the Chances are in a constant struggle to make ends meet - honestly. That's why so many viewers are attracted to the story, she believes.

"The show has a naturally, inherently dark, weird, unattractive element to it," Plimpton said. "It's not completely realistic, obviously. Garret and I are obviously very sexy and very hot, but our characters are not. Our characters are run-of-the-mill loser-y, not terribly sharp, and so, as a family, we're struggling. These are struggling people who are outside the realm of comfort and success, in a way you don't often see on television.

"The other thing about it is, there's no cynicism here. It's not hateful. Even though it's dark and weird and we're throwing up on children and whatnot, it's not ugly, it's not hurtful, it's not mean. I think that's something we're thirsty for in the culture. We want something a little more honest and human, but that doesn't mean it can't come with foibles. It can be messed up, it can be ugly and messy, but it doesn't have to be cruel.

"That's my guess, anyway. I'm not an expert. I'm not out there in the field with a questionnaire, but my guess is that has something to do with it."

Raising Hope is all about managing expectations, in other words. In comedy, as in life.

(Citytv, 9:30 ET/PT; FOX, 8 ET/PT)

Three to see:

• Arctic Air closes the book on its first season with an episode about a routine flight between Watson Lake and Yellowknife that goes awry, with deadly results. A second season has yet to be confirmed, but early signs look encouraging - unlike the flight in tonight's season finale. (CBC, 9 ET/PT)

• As if the hapless crew of the Magus didn't have enough to worry about in The River - ghostly firelight, spectral visions, creepy dolls, something hidden and nasty in the brackish water, a riverboat version of the Flying Dutchman - now they have to worry about cannibals.

Which may not work out for anyone, if you think about it, including the cannibals. By this stage of the expedition, the lost explorers are looking a tad underfed.

(CTV, ABC, 9 ET/PT)

• Cee Lo Green, of The Voice fame and infamy, reads tonight's Top Ten List on David Letterman's Late Show, preferably with Purrfect in his arms. Letterman's guests include Parks and Recreation resident scene-stealer, Nick Offerman, and a musical performance by Celtic folk group, The Chieftains, and the Providence, R.I. indie band, Low Anthem. (Local stations, CBS, 11:35 ET/PT)
